titleproper.value:
Guide to the Peter Weiss Papers
                    <num>TAM.638</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Heather Mulliner

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2015-01-12T14:24-0500</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: This collection contains the personal and professional papers of human rights attorney Peter Weiss (1925- ). Born in Austria in 1925, Weiss moved to the U.S. in 1941 and worked as a lawyer from 1955 to 2006. This collection contains materials related to Weiss's professional career and his involvement in human rights issues. Materials contained within this collection include notes, research materials, published and unpublished works created between 1963 and 1993, personal and professional correspondence written between the 1940s and the 1990s, travel itineraries, transcripts, and ephemera related to Weiss's numerous speaking engagements.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Peter Weiss Papers; TAM 638; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Peter Weiss sent a gift of four boxes of personal and professional papers in 2013. The accession number associated with this gift is 2013.045.
He is married to human rights activist Cora Weiss.

Materials in this collection have been rehoused into archival folders, and Weiss's original folder titles have been maintained as much as possible. Files labeled "Traces" contain an assortment of correspondence, clippings, articles, and notes related to Weiss's career and personal life. Files labeled "Opera" contain transcripts, articles, pamphlets, and correspondence related to a wide variety of international human rights issues. Other files, labeled "Orlando" specifically relate to the investigation surrounding the assassination of Orlando Letelier, these files are primarily comprised of newspapers clippings and correspondence with Letelier's family.
